qa_pairs.question: How did the design and production materials of Series I and Series II notes differ, and what unique security features were incorporated into each series?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Series I notes were influenced by American currency designs, while Series II notes had a front design similar to Series I but with updated dates and details.<cite>[S12][S20]</cite></statement> <statement>Series I notes were printed on polymer Tyvek paper, whereas Series II notes used cotton-fibre paper.<cite>[S14][S20]</cite></statement> <statement>Series I notes featured a unique hologram different from the currency issue, while Series II notes incorporated a security hologram with an albatross bird that appears to fly when viewed through a special device.<cite>[S16][S23][S24]</cite></statement> <statement>Both series were dual-denominated in cents and dollars, but Series I included $3 and $15 denominations, while Series II introduced an $8 note.<cite>[S8][S12][S19]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] History of Chatham Islands numismatics


# History of Chatham Islands numismatics



In 1999 a private organisation, the Chatham Islands Note Corporation, issued banknotes to celebrate the Chatham Islands being the first human-inhabited land to enter the third millennium. [S2] Banknotes such as these cannot be declared legal tender, and there is no obligation for anyone to accept the notes issued by the Chatham Island Note Corporation in any transaction. [S3] These notes were reported to have been accepted by merchants on the Chatham Islands, some of whom served as directors of the issuer. [S4] The Chatham Islands Note Corporation was initially based in Christchurch. [S5] The agent for providing the notes to the numismatic trade was Leon Morel, Fellow of the Royal Numismatic Society of New Zealand of Melbourne, Victoria. [S6] The corporation later shifted their base of operations to Waitangi. [S7] The face value of the notes was pegged at the same rate as the New Zealand dollar. [S8] They are unusual in that the first series included $3 and $15 notes, while the second series includes an $8 note. [S9] ## Not legal tender

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand clarified that these notes are not legal tender. [S10] The Reserve Bank Deputy Governor Murray Sherwin mentioned that "Whilst these Chatham Island dollars are a bit of fun,... [S11] if people want to use them to undertake transactions, that's fine too."


## The series

Series I notes consist of $2, $3, $10 and $15 denominations, and exhibit a very strong influence from American currency designs. [S12] There were printed in late 1999, still in time for their release on January 1, 2000. [S13] They were printed on polymer Tyvek paper with the artwork by Timely Marketing & Promotions Limited, Christchurch and Dunedin, New Zealand. [S14] Tyvek is a plastic-type material, and the notes are dual-denominated—in cents as well as in dollars. [S15] The same-numbered sets which came out in cardboard folders, also bear a completely different hologram, as compared to the currency issue. [S16] There are three printings of this series. [S17] Full sets of this series are now scarce. [S18] Series II notes, consisting of $3, $5, $8, $10 and $15 denominations, were printed some time during the year 2000 for release in 2001. [S19] They were printed on cotton-fibre paper by Chan Wanich Security Printing Company Limited, Thailand. [S20] The front of these notes is very similar to the Series I notes, apart from the dates and other details. [S21] Again, these notes are dual-denominated in cents and dollars. [S22] There are also three printings of this series with same-serial numbered sets produced, but not in cardboard folders, having a different hologram than the first currency issue. [S23] This hologram is unique in that it incorporates an albatross bird that flies when viewed through a special security device. [S24] In 2001, a $5 coin was put into circulation at the same time as the Series II notes. [S25] A 5,000 piece issue was then planned; however, informed of the intention to issue a coin, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand banned the issue, despite the fact that there was no $5 coin in circulation in New Zealand. [S26] An estimated 200 pieces ended up in the numismatic trade. [S27] The balance, other than a remaining 100 held by CINC, were never minted. [S28] ## Description

To assist collectors and dealers, a catalogue numbering system has been provided. [S29] Below, 'Work' numbers (indicated by the letter 'W') to the items, have been assigned for clarity. [S30] ### Series I

qa_pairs.question: What led to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's intervention regarding the planned $5 coin, and what was the outcome of this action?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Reserve Bank of New Zealand intervened regarding the planned $5 coin due to the Chatham Islands Note Corporation's intention to issue it, even though no $5 coin existed in New Zealand's circulation at the time.<cite>[S25][S26]</cite></statement><statement>The outcome of the intervention was that the Reserve Bank banned the $5 coin's issuance, resulting in only an estimated 200 pieces entering the numismatic trade, while the remaining planned coins were never minted.<cite>[S26][S27][S28]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: How do the $5 and $50 milled edge coins issued by the Chatham Islands Note Corporation serve as dual commemoratives, and what specific historical elements are referenced on their obverse and reverse designs?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The $5 and $50 milled edge coins issued by the Chatham Islands Note Corporation serve as dual commemoratives by marking the Millennium and specific historical events. The $5 coin commemorates the Millennium and the heritage of the Moriori people, while the $50 coin marks the Millennium and the 210th anniversary of the British discovery of the Chatham Islands.<cite>[S193][S194]</cite></statement><statement>The $5 coin's obverse features a head-and-shoulders portrait of Tommy Solomon, the last full-blooded Moriori, splitting the date '2001,' with the inscription 'FIVE NEW MILLENNIUM DOLLARS' below. Its reverse displays a map of the Chatham Islands with the text 'CHATHAM ISLANDS NEW ZEALAND TERRITORIES SOUTH PACIFIC' and the denomination '$5.'<cite>[S176][S177][S178][S179][S180]</cite></statement><statement>The $50 coin's obverse includes a portrait of King George III, referencing British history, with the inscription 'CHATHAM ISLANDS' above and the dates '1760–1820' below. Its reverse depicts a compass, a ship, and an 18th-century Royal Navy officer's hat, alongside inscriptions detailing the discovery of the Chatham Islands and the denomination '50.'<cite>[S181][S182][S183][S184][S185][S186][S187][S188][S189][S190][S191][S192]</cite></statement>

[S175] $5 Milled Edge Coin 1-1/4 inches (30 mm) in diameter

Limited number (less than 300 are known to exist) - Now scarce

* Obverse: A head-and-shoulders portrait of Tommy Solomon (born 1884, died 1933. [S176] Popularly believed to have been the last full-blooded Moriori) splitting the date '2001'. [S177] The inscription,'FIVE NEW MILLENNIUM DOLLARS' is below the portrait. [S178] * Reverse: Map of the Chatham Islands with '$5' below. [S179] It is inscribed, 'CHATHAM ISLANDS NEW ZEALAND TERRITORIES SOUTH PACIFIC'. [S180] ### WCII. [S181] Sterling Silver $50 Milled Edge Coin 1.5 inches (38 mm) in diameter

Scarce

* Obverse: A portrait of King George III (ruled 1760–1820) based on Benedetto Pistrucci's portrait as used on the British 1/2 Crown of 1817–20, the 5-shilling (1 Crown) of 1818–20, 1/2 Sovereign of 1817–20, the Sovereign of 1818 and 1820, the 2 pounds and 5 pounds pattern coins of 1820. [S182] The monogram 'G III' is split at the forehead level. [S183] The inscription, 'CHATHAM ISLANDS' is above the King's portrait. [S184] The dates '1760–1820' are inscribed below the chin. [S185] The date '2001' appears below the truncation. [S186] The inscription, 'FIFTY DOLLAR MILLENNIUM SILVER PIECE' goes from behind the King's portrait around to the front at eye level. [S187] * Reverse: The design is a compass pointing North, a ship, and an 18th-century Royal Navy officer's hat with the number '50' superimposed on the hat. [S188] The outer inscriptions are 'LIEUT BROUGHTON. [S189] BRIG CHATHAM 1791'. [S190] The inner inscription is 'DISCOVERY OF THE CHATHAM ISLANDS 44 DEG S LAT 176 DEG 20 MIN W LONG'. [S191] The inscription 'FIFTY DOLLAR PIECE' appears below the '50'. [S192] * The $50 coin is a dual commemorative: The Millennium and the 210th Anniversary of the British discovery of the Chatham Islands. [S193] * Both the $5 and the $50 coins have milled edges. qa_pairs.question: What distinguishes the 'same-serial numbered folder issue' from 'printer's specimen' and 'replacement note' variants in the Chatham Islands currency series, and how are these variants identified in the source context?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The 'same-serial numbered folder issue' refers to notes within the Chatham Islands currency series that share identical serial numbers, as indicated by entries like W1b, W2b, W3b, etc., which specify "Same-serial numbered folder issue" [S43][S51][S59][S67][S84][S98][S113][S127][S141][S150][S152]. These variants are distinguished by their uniform serial numbering, unlike other variants. <cite>[S43][S51][S59][S67][S84][S98][S113][S127][S141][S150][S152]</cite></statement><statement>The 'printer's specimen' variant is identified by a unique serial number format, specifically "A000000," as noted in entries like W5p, W6p, W7p, and W8p, which are labeled "(Printer's Specimen)" [S87][S89][S101][S103][S116][S118][S130][S132][S144][S146]. These specimens were likely produced for testing or archival purposes. <cite>[S87][S89][S101][S103][S116][S118][S130][S132][S144][S146]</cite></statement><statement>The 'replacement note' variant is characterized by a serial number ending with a star symbol, as seen in entries like W5r, W6r, W7r, and W8r, which are labeled "(Replacement note)" [S91][S105][S120][S134][S148]. These notes were presumably issued to replace defective or damaged currency. <cite>[S91][S105][S120][S134][S148]</cite></statement><statement>The key distinction lies in the serial number characteristics: same-serial numbered folder issues share identical numbers, printer's specimens use "A000000," and replacement notes have a star suffix. These identifiers are explicitly stated in the source context for each variant. <cite>[S36][S87][S91][S101][S105][S116][S120][S130][S134][S144][S148]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What role do the Chatham Islands black robin and albatross motifs play in the design of the currency notes, and how do these elements align with the thematic focus of specific denominations?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The Chatham Islands black robin motif appears on multiple currency denominations, each aligning with specific thematic focuses. For instance, on the $2 note, it is paired with the theme "The Sea," depicted on the back alongside a lobster and the sea. On the $3 note, it is associated with "The Community," alongside a first motor vehicle. The $10 note links the black robin to "The History" theme, while the $15 note connects it to "The Land," alongside elements like the Nīkau palm and Chathams' horse power.<cite>[S40][S48][S56][S64]</cite></statement><statement>The albatross motif replaces the Chatham Islands map in Series II notes, as described in the supporting context. However, the specific thematic alignment of the albatross with denominations is not explicitly detailed in the provided text, though it may reflect broader ecological or regional symbolism tied to the Chatham Islands.<cite>[S71]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What were the primary motivations for the Chatham Islands Note Corporation's issuance of banknotes in 1999, and how did the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's clarification regarding their legal tender status interact with the corporation's objectives?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The primary motivation for the Chatham Islands Note Corporation's issuance of banknotes in 1999 was to celebrate the Chatham Islands being the first human-inhabited land to enter the third millennium.<cite>[S1]</cite></statement><statement>The Reserve Bank of New Zealand clarified that these notes are not legal tender, emphasizing that there is no obligation for anyone to accept them in transactions.<cite>[S9]</cite></statement><statement>Despite this clarification, the notes were reported to have been accepted by some merchants on the Chatham Islands, including those who served as directors of the issuer, aligning with the corporation's objective of creating a symbolic commemorative currency.<cite>[S3]</cite></statement><statement>The Reserve Bank's statement did not directly conflict with the corporation's goals, as the notes were intended as a novelty rather than a replacement for legal tender, with the Deputy Governor acknowledging that using them for transactions was "a bit of fun" and permissible if voluntary.<cite>[S10][S11]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] History of Chatham Islands numismatics


# History of Chatham Islands numismatics



In 1999 a private organisation, the Chatham Islands Note Corporation, issued banknotes to celebrate the Chatham Islands being the first human-inhabited land to enter the third millennium. [S2] Banknotes such as these cannot be declared legal tender, and there is no obligation for anyone to accept the notes issued by the Chatham Island Note Corporation in any transaction. [S3] These notes were reported to have been accepted by merchants on the Chatham Islands, some of whom served as directors of the issuer. [S4] The Chatham Islands Note Corporation was initially based in Christchurch. [S5] The agent for providing the notes to the numismatic trade was Leon Morel, Fellow of the Royal Numismatic Society of New Zealand of Melbourne, Victoria. [S6] The corporation later shifted their base of operations to Waitangi. [S7] The face value of the notes was pegged at the same rate as the New Zealand dollar. [S8] They are unusual in that the first series included $3 and $15 notes, while the second series includes an $8 note. [S9] ## Not legal tender

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand clarified that these notes are not legal tender. [S10] The Reserve Bank Deputy Governor Murray Sherwin mentioned that "Whilst these Chatham Island dollars are a bit of fun,... [S11] if people want to use them to undertake transactions, that's fine too."


## The series

Series I notes consist of $2, $3, $10 and $15 denominations, and exhibit a very strong influence from American currency designs. [S12] There were printed in late 1999, still in time for their release on January 1, 2000. [S13] They were printed on polymer Tyvek paper with the artwork by Timely Marketing & Promotions Limited, Christchurch and Dunedin, New Zealand. [S14] Tyvek is a plastic-type material, and the notes are dual-denominated—in cents as well as in dollars. [S15] The same-numbered sets which came out in cardboard folders, also bear a completely different hologram, as compared to the currency issue. [S16] There are three printings of this series. [S17] Full sets of this series are now scarce. [S18] Series II notes, consisting of $3, $5, $8, $10 and $15 denominations, were printed some time during the year 2000 for release in 2001. [S19] They were printed on cotton-fibre paper by Chan Wanich Security Printing Company Limited, Thailand. [S20] The front of these notes is very similar to the Series I notes, apart from the dates and other details. [S21] Again, these notes are dual-denominated in cents and dollars. [S22] There are also three printings of this series with same-serial numbered sets produced, but not in cardboard folders, having a different hologram than the first currency issue. [S23] This hologram is unique in that it incorporates an albatross bird that flies when viewed through a special security device. [S24] In 2001, a $5 coin was put into circulation at the same time as the Series II notes. [S25] A 5,000 piece issue was then planned; however, informed of the intention to issue a coin, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand banned the issue, despite the fact that there was no $5 coin in circulation in New Zealand. [S26] An estimated 200 pieces ended up in the numismatic trade. [S27] The balance, other than a remaining 100 held by CINC, were never minted. [S28] ## Description

To assist collectors and dealers, a catalogue numbering system has been provided. [S29] Below, 'Work' numbers (indicated by the letter 'W') to the items, have been assigned for clarity. [S30] ### Series I
